And technically no physical information can travel faster than light, but gravity isn't information, and gravity can warp speed.
Technically waves can have mass as long as there frequency and wavelength don't multiply to numbers passed 186,000 miles per second.
And particles don't have amplitude or peaks (crests and troughs), wavelength, or repeating cycles.
Waves don't have spin, unless there carried by the EM force.
Fermions such as quarks and leptons have a 1/2 integer spin, unlike bosons, which have a derivative spin.
Angular momentum is when you position your moving mass on an x, y and z axis.
A wave is when gravity stretches and contracts travelling information. A particle is when gravity holds information still and considers angular momentum.
Waves actually behave the way they do becauee they are being bent do to gravity. Gravity can attract, orbit, spin, loop, and amplify.
I think there is small error in one of the slides at 4:58. The intensity becomes proportional to 1/r^4 and not 1/r^2.

I have a question. In the case of constructive superposition, each pulse has an energy of .5×kA^2. It means that the energy in the system is kA^2. But when they superpose, the amplitude becomes 2A. Then the energy in the system is
.5×k×(2A)^2=2×kA^2
Where does the extra energy comes from?

The animation at 2:02 has a fault. The intention is to show the difference in travel speed in different mediums. The blue waveform has to travel faster as the pink one. About x5 judging by the wavelengths. What the animation actually shows is two waves with different frequencies traveling in the same medium.
